reviewText:
Nice little casual game: not only the music is good but the story is also well written - I didn't really find any plothole (apart how the captain and our heroin seemed in love without any indication from her to have feelings). I find also the place very great: it's a boat and you're staying in it. Though the map isn't interactive at all, it's easy to find your way.

The minigames themselves are varied and I've appreciated the timed ones - though 3 minutes is too long for my taste. And the HOG are also challenging: some items are really obvious while others, being partially hidden or really well hidden to the point where you think they're part of the scenery or another object, are quite challenging.

You can also replay the HO or the minigames in the menu, which is a nice bonus.

Not the casual game of the year but very very refreshing game.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but unfortunately it is just not very well designed or put together.

Interface and Difficulty Settings:

The interface seems simple enough: a hand icon will appear if you can manipulate something, a spyglass icon will appear if you can examine something, and a glowing arrow will appear if you can move to a new location; however, there is no icon for whether you can pick something up, so have fun clicking on every object in a room or background to see if your character feels like taking it. There is also an issue with needing pixel accuracy for certain item interactions.

The only difference between normal and advanced difficulties is that the normal mode will sometimes, if it feels like it, make certain interactables (usually pearls) sparkle. It is a bit buggy, though, because it will also make areas where you have already picked things up sparkle, or areas where there is absolutely nothing of interest sparkle. Hidden object screens in both difficulties are clearly noted.

Hidden Object Puzzles:

You would think that the items would be pretty clearly distinguishable from each other, since each object is a separate cg-rendered model, but everything looks like it's made out of the same cheap plastic; if two items have a similar colour, they just blend together.

The puzzles at least make a bit more sense than most in the genre - the kitchen contains cooking-related items, the first-aid kit contains medical supplies, and the crew quarters and storerooms contain a wider assortment of gear and personal effects. There aren't too many piles of junk, or random Victorian dolls, or vegetables mixed in with antiques like you see in other HOGs.

One slightly irksome thing is that interactables within the hidden object screens are not indicated in any way, so any of the items stashed within containers or compartments are especially difficult to locate. It kind of defeats the purpose of strategic hunting if you have to randomly click on everything that might be a secret cache.

Additionally, at least two of the puzzles have random insects crawling all over them for atmosphere
date:
so I hope you like bugs.

Mini-games:

Speaking of creepy crawlies, I hope you also like rats and spiders because they each have their own mini-game.

I will at least give this game props for creativity.

Some of mini-games were tedious, and involved either do this repetitive thing for a full three minutes" or "see how fast you can click and drag." Other mini-games were actually fun
hoursPlayed: and were different from any of the formulaic genre standards. I especially liked the match-3 tile-flipping game.\n\nAt the completion of each puzzle
voteText: a little victory jingle plays

votesHelpful:
but I just opened a door. Party time!"

There is also a game-wide hidden object puzzle of finding little pearls hidden all over the ship. I like that the game adds another layer of complexity with this challenge.

Story:

There is also a weird quasi-romantic scene shoehorned in for no reason.

reviewText:
Short version: 72%Night Mysteries is a hidden object game that also tries to be a lightweight Lovecraftian horror story on board of a seemingly abandoned ship, and it does a surprisingly good job at both.

Long version:Night Mysteries: The Amphora Prisoner is the first time Anvate Games tried itself at the hidden object genre, and for a starting project, it is an incredibly positive surprise.

The biggest of these surprises is the story: we follow a struggling young writer called Natalie, who– while being on board a ship to America– has to battle an undescribed mysterious force in order to save the missing crew. There are some problems with the pacing and the out-of-place minigames, but even they cannot put a dent into the great, eerie atmosphere that accompanies us from start to finish. In this regard, Night Mysteries outclasses many large-budget hidden object games.

As for gameplay, it relies on some really outdated hidden object mechanics, and I swear this is the first HOG I met where the bonus collectibles are promoted into a mandatory element. Still, some parts are clever and refreshing, and even the worst parts are more than tolerable, so, altogether, this is a really solid product for any HOG fan.

reviewText:
Written As of 6/1/2015: & there are no present plans by the creators to add them.
There are no Achievements.
There are no Cards.
Overview	     This game is by no means a Hard Puzzle Game. You won't get frustrated trying to figure out where to go since the game includes subtle hints in your journal as well as hints on locked doors.  This is an extremely casual puzzle adventure game fit for any age. The only thing I could think of that might be slightly inappropriate is the ending where the Captain & Protagonist hold each other suggestively.

The Story	     You're a writer traveling to America after the death of your father.  You unfortunately miss your boat by 3 minutes and wander the harbor looking for another ride.  Meeting the Captain of another ship, he agrees to take you on also subtly informing you that they're holding cargo for an antique dealer. After meeting and greeting the crew you settling in your room and then fall asleep. Barely minutes after falling asleep you wake up greeted by an eerie sound produced throughout the ship that gives you goosebumps. Your adventure begins as you try to find the source of the sound...

Youtube Walkthrough Link - Click Below	 My Youtube Walkthrough

Took me 1:40:00 to clear game w/ some hints
(used towards finding Some H.O.[Hidden Object], 33rd pearl, & wire for Ship's Wheel)
Walkthrough is approximately 1:00:00.

H.O.S." - Hidden Object Scene *Spoilers Ahead*
There are two places where you might get lost since no hints are given:
Trying to lift the bar closing the kitchen?  Go to Left side Upper Deck
date:
H.O.S. on the pile of metal.
Trying to Lock the Ship's Wheel? Go to radio room and use Shears on wire under desk.

There's only one pearl that is hidden quite well
recommended: the rest are out of the open - Left side Upper Deck

reviewText:
This is an original, excellent, but flawed take on the hidden-object scene genre.

It's quite hard: some of the hidden-objects scenes and puzzles would be difficult to solve if you're not very experienced with the way in which such games try to trick you.  I found one puzzle impossible to solve without skipping, and I'm usually quite good at these! Likewise, the point-and-click adventuring is not easy. Luckily, you can use the hint key without penalty.

Despite the difficult, it is fair. The ship is not very big, and you can wander back and forth without frustration until you think of a way to solve a problem.

Also nice is that the collectibles are actually part of the game. It's fun finding them on your own, and then looking for them more carefully in the end in order to finish.

The graphics, a mix of 3D models, gently swaying in the ocean ways, and drawn cut scenes, are terrific and capture the eerie mood very well. The story is cliché but told simply and without nonsense.

Unfortunately, the game engine is a bit buggy. There were a few places where clicking the first time didn't register for me. Also, there are a few scenes where you have to use mouse gesturing to move through them. I found these buggy and frustrating experiences, and unlike the puzzles they are not skippable. I think they don't really have a place in this genre, and the game would be better without them.

reviewText:
Good story.
After the death of your father, you miss your boat back to the US. But a friendly cargo captain accepts to bring you aboard. He explains that it is usually very boring voyages, taking cargo from Europe to the US, but with her, the conversation are different and refreshing. He explains that on this voyage, he's carrying some antics for a collector.
On the first night, she can't sleep because of a weird noise. She gets up to find the source of the noise. You investigation and mystery solving starts now. I'm not saying anything else. Enjoy!
I recommend.

reviewText: Hidden object / puzzles with an interesting story.\nThis not-too-long game tells a compelling tale where you find yourself wandering about a ship trying to save the crew from an evil spirit in an artifact. The puzzles and hidden object screens provide a challenge without being too difficult and the puzzles are varied  eg jigsaws, matching pairs, avoiding obstacles and even spraying rats away! All are fun, and not too difficult. Hardcore players will probably find it not challenging enough and perhaps a little short but if you're looking for something to pass the time while thinking things out a little, this game is for you.

reviewText:
I have played many HOG in the past and this is really unique in one way: graphics. Instead of hand-drawn pictures, everything is in 3D. There's no way to rotate the camera or use this feature, so there game is still a common 2D HOG, with a bit of a graphics twist in it. It was hard to accept first, but I got used to it fast.

About voices. There's no voice acting, just subtitles. Anyway, that's not the worst problem with this game.

Story is plain simple, there are no real twist in it. It's boring as hell, although it's really short. You can finish this game in 1.5 hours which is *really* short - even for a HOG.

There are some interesting and fun mini-game in this game, but there are a couple of irritating one too. Some has a countdown timer and you have to do the same boring stuff for 3 minutes! It's fun for 10-20 secs but after that, you just want to finish it and move forward. Fortunately you can skip this parts after a minute or so. I found find-by-name" mini-games sadistic and annoying. There are some puzzles which require specific skills from the player (not so causal) like getting water from the sea. It's really simple: click then hold it while you have to move your mouse up
date: in reality it's just not working. After a couple of tries I chose to skip them as well.\n\nAvoid this game. Believe me
recommended: you can find much better HOG out there!"

reviewText:
I love casual games that involve puzzles, gentle story nothing to overbearing and especially hidden object games.

This game however just really frustrated me. One 'puzzle' involved me putting out a fire and having to find a bucket, fill it up with water and actually repeat this process a couple of times for it to work. What irritated me to no end was the fact that I was passing through loads of rooms with bloody fire extinguishers in them. Why am I getting a bucket and dipping it in the sea when I can use those? There's actually more than one too!

The hidden object games are frustrating as well. The 'art' of them is not having them completely hidden but cleverly blending them in the with the background. SEASON OF MYSTERY: The Cherry Blossom Murders does this brilliantly, Night Mysteries: The Amphora Prisoner, imo doesn't.

I will say however it is a nice touch offering the puzzles and hidden object games on the main menu, I just felt some of the stuff in the actual game was so frustrating.

reviewText:
Hübsches Wimmelbildspiel. Interessante Geschichte. Man merkt, dass der Entwickler sich Mühe gegeben hat, die Gegenstände zu verstecken. Was natürlich dazu führt, dass manche extrem schwer zu finden sind. Vor allem die Teile, die hinter anderen versteckt sind....da hilft nichts außer alles auf dem Schirm abzuklicken, denn einen Hinweis darauf gibt es nicht. OH, und manche Teile sind wirklich extrem klein...viel Spass beim Perlensuchen ;-)
Natürlich ist dieses kein Adventure. Das bedeutet wieder mal, dass man mehr Zeit darauf verwendet den nächsten Hot Spot zu finden. Es gibt zwar eine Karte aber anscheinend keine Schnellreise Funktion.
Nachdem man das Spiel durch hat (bei mir mit Pause keine 3 Stunden) kann man die 13 Puzzles und 11 HOGs im Menue auch seperat anwählen. Aber.....so berauschend sind sie nun auch wieder nicht.

Empfehlen kann ich es allen, die gute Augen haben ;)

reviewText: This game was ok, but I found it rather frustrating and ended up using hints more often than I prefer to be able to find objects or know what to do next, and I played it on casual/easy mode. A previous review had mentioned that there was no icon to indicate an item could be collected, so I was aware of that going into the game, but it was incredibly difficult to find necessary items. You had to click on a specific part of some items to be able to collect it/use it, and for items in hidden object scenes that need an extra step to find, it was nearly impossible to find it as you just have to click everywhere possible. When a new item is needed to move forward in the game, you need to backtrack and search everywhere possible to find either a new hidden object scene or some new area to interact with, again without an icon showing you an item you can suddenly interact with. The map only shows you where you are, not any area with an available action, so that was no help at all during the game - same with the journal. The story was interesting, but left a lot up to the imagination to fill in storyline gaps. If it's on sale, it's an alright way to spend some time, but otherwise it just isn't worth it.
